newsitem.title: CANADA: Fletcher's would consider new hog futures.
newsitem.headline: Fletcher's would consider new hog futures.

text.p: One of western Canada's largest hog processors said on Tuesday it would consider hedging its price risk on futures contracts in hog carcass cuts not currently available.

"One of the limitations for a packer buying his hogs forward is the ability to sell his finished goods forward and that's what we're missing right now," Fletcher's Fine Foods Ltd vice-president Greg Whalley told the Canadian Wheat Board's Grain World conference delegates here.
Canadian packers currently hedge by using the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's cash-settled lean-hog carcass and pork belly contracts.

Asked by a grain grower whether Fletcher's would hedge on a lean, barley-fed hog futures contract now being drafted by the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, Whalley said: "There's very little we can sell forward. We can sell bellies on the Merc, but there isn't much opportunity to sell any other cuts forward so we could properly hedge," he said.
Fletcher's invested C$23 million late last year to expand the annual hog kill capacity at its packing plant in Red Deer, Alberta, to two million hogs from one million, he said.
The expansion was done with a view to increase pork exports to the Pacific Rim and the U.S. to between 40 to 50 percent.
The Pacific Rim is the main target market for western Canada's burgeoning pork industry.
Japanese consumers buy hog loins while Korea is a noted consumer of hog bellies, Canadian pork analysts said.
Whalley said most Prairie pork packing in the future would likely be done under long-term contracts with producers.
Canada's largest grain handler, Saskatchewan Wheat Pool, acquired a 35 percent stake in Fletcher's Feb 10.
SWP said it bought into Fletcher's with the aim of doubling Saskatchewan's output to two million hogs a year within five years from the current one million hogs.
The grain handler got approval Feb 24 to issue public shares in a hog farrow-to-finish subsidiary that would operate barns throughout Saskatchewan.
